text: That's an interesting question. I think it gets down to the idea of, are these intangible factors like a risk premium, a risk factor, or are they a mispricing, like an alpha? And I think the explanation is a bit of both. It is the case, for example, on the R&D front that these are some costs. I put about 10 million bucks into cancer research and it doesn't pan out. Well, that's most likely going to be worth zero. Same with some of the other intangibles. And in many ways, it can be boom or bust. I think I talked about an example of like Medo, which is kind of one of the cheapest of the faying stocks. We'll put it on Netflix. Cheapest of the tech giants. And part of the reason is because they're investing 10 billion plus in the metaverse every year. And then investors are like, is this just a science fiction fantasy? Is this a real thing? And maybe it'll turn out in 10 years that the metaverse is huge and Facebook owns it, or maybe not. But that sort of bet is pretty challenging for investors to stomach. And as a result, it leads to these firms being punished with regards to their PEs. So that would be the risk-based explanation. On the alpha explanation, I think it's even simpler, which is to say that these intangibles are hard to measure. Most of the world, all these kind of passive investors and active investors as well are very focused on accounting data. They're also very short-term focused, trailing quarterly earnings. And to the extent that say long-term deep scientific research may have a huge impact on a 10-year horizon, but is a cost over a one-quarter horizon, maybe it's the case that it's overlooked or perhaps underappreciated by the market. So I think either of these two things are probably a valid explanation and probably they're both to some extent applicable.
